Treponemes are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.

questions.text: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section is shown below. Identify the staining method.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards the diagnosis of syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.

It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: What type of motility is shown by Treponema pallidum?
questions.solution:
Treponema pallidum show corkscrew motility, i.e movement by rotation around the long axis.

The characteristic feature of spirochetes is the presence of endoflagella, situated between the outer membrane and cell wall, that facilitates this movement.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant lady tests VDRL positive at her 1st-trimester antenatal check-up. An FTA-ABS confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is a false statement about the organism causing this disease?

choices.text: It cannot be cultured in vitro
Endoflagella is in the periplasmic space.
Humans are the only known natural hosts

questions.solution:
VDRL positive status is suggestive of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) is a confirmatory test.

Reiter’s strain is a cultivable, non-pathogenic treponeme, showing morphological and antigenic similarities with T.pallidum. It is widely used as the antigen in group-specific treponemal tests for the diagnosis of syphilis.  

Nichol's strain is virulent and non-cultivable in artificial media. However, it can be grown in cell culture through serial passage in live rabbit testes.

questions.text: A patient had a solitary, painless penile ulcer 2 months back. Now, he presents with a generalized maculopapular rash over the body. What is the sensitivity of VDRL at this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of VDRL is 100% in secondary syphilis. History of solitary painless ulcer with a generalized maculopapular rash is consistent with secondary syphilis. 

The VDRL test becomes positive 4–5 weeks after exposure to T. pallidum and 1–2 weeks after the appearance of the chancre.

The VDRL test is a highly sensitive test. The sensitivity of the test depends on the stage of the disease:

  • Primary syphilis- 60–75% 
  • Secondary syphilis- 100%
  • High antibody titers may be found in patients developing gummatous lesions and neurovascular or cardiovascular complications.
  • Tertiary syphilis- usually negative
  • Negative test:
    • Early primary syphilis
    • Latent acquired syphilis
    • Late congenital syphilis

Secondary syphilis is the most infective stage in the course of the illness. The patient may present with a roseolar or papular skin rash, condyloma lata, and mucous patches. 

The image below shows lesions of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the serological tests of syphilis?

choices.text: Rapid plasma reagin test is a group specific treponemal test
VDRL test is the test of choice for response to therapy
VDRL is the test of choice for examining CSF
Treponemal tests are likely to remain reactive even after adequate therapy

questions.solution:
RPR is a non-specific test. It uses the VDRL antigen (cardiolipin) containing carbon particles. Hence, results can be seen by the naked eye, whereas VDRL requires a microscope for visualization of flocculation. 

The test of choice for monitoring response to treatment and for examining CSF is VDRL  

The test of choice for syphilis screening is RPR. 

After treatment, in early syphilis,

  • Non-treponemal tests- titers decline or become non-reactive 
  • Treponemal tests- remain reactive

For diagnosis of syphilis, a 2 test approach is used i.e., screening with an NTT (non-treponemal test) which includes either VDRL or RPR. Confirmation of syphilis is done by a treponemal test, most commonly by TPHA (Treponema pallidum hemagglutination test).

Follow-up is done using NTT (as treponemal tests remains positive for years after treatment).

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: A 55-year old man was brought to the OPD with complaints of rapid decline in cognition, impaired position, and vibratory sense. There is a history of sporadic short-term relationships with many promiscuous sexual partners. Romberg’s sign is positive and bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils are seen on checking for pupillary reflex. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above with a positive sexual history, Romberg test, and Argyll Robertson pupils is suggestive of neurosyphilis. The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

The CSF VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/μL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

questions.text: You treated a case of secondary syphilis with a single dose of benzathine penicillin-G 2.4 million IU IM. What follow-up advice would you give for the assessment of the patient's response to treatment?

choices.text: Follow up with VDRL after 6 months and 12 months
Follow up with VDRL after 3 months and 6 months
Follow up with TPHA after 6 months and 12 months
Follow up with TPHA after 3 months  and 6 months

questions.solution:
The investigation used to assess response to treatment in syphilis is VDRL. In the case of secondary syphilis, follow-up VDRL should be done at 6 months and 12 months.

VDRL and RPR become negative after adequate treatment whereas specific treponemal tests remain positive indefinitely despite treatment.

Guidelines for follow up:

  • Patients with primary or secondary syphilis should be examined 6 and 12 months after treatment.
  • Patients with latent or late syphilis should be examined at 6, 12, and 24 months after treatment.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestational age tested VDRL positive but negative for specific treponemal tests. What is your interpretation?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy can give rise to false-positive VDRL.

Biological false-positive (BFP) reactions are defined as positive reactions obtained in non-specific treponemal tests (RPR, VDRL) with negative results in specific treponemal tests, in the absence of past or present treponemal infections and not caused by technical faults.

Related Pearl: Biological False Positive reactions in serologic testing of syphilis

Acute biological false-positive reactions are seen in (<6 months):

  • Pregnancy
  • Upper respiratory tract infections
  • Measles
  • Chickenpox
  • Hepatitis
  • Viral pneumonia
  • Malaria 
  • Following vaccination and immunization
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Chancroid
  • Tuberculosis
  • Pneumococcal pneumonia
  • Leptospirosis

Chronic biological false-positive reactions are seen in (>6 months):  

  • Leprosy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Leukemia
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Metastatic carcinoma

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with a runny nose and bullous lesions on the skin and legs. Her X-ray (given below) showed features suggestive of periostitis. Which of the following is the initial investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The newborn baby has characteristic signs and symptoms of congenital syphilis. Periostitis is a hallmark of skeletal manifestation. VDRL or RPR is the initial investigation of choice in congenital syphilis.

The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly,  lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

All neonates born to mothers who have reactive nontreponemal and treponemal test results should be evaluated with a quantitative nontreponemal serologic test (RPR or VDRL) performed on the neonate’s serum, because umbilical cord blood can become contaminated with maternal blood and yield a false-positive result.

FTA-ABS or TPHA is used for confirmation of syphilis in a patient with reactive RPR or VDRL test.
T. pallidum cannot be detected by culture.

questions.text: What is the causative agent of yaws ?
questions.solution:
Causative agent of yaws is Treponema pertenue.

It is one of the endemic treponematoses that spreads by direct contact.

The image shows ulcerative skin lesions seen in yaws.

questions.text: What is the causative organism and the corresponding vector for epidemic relapsing fever?
questions.solution:
Epidemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis and is transmitted by louse.

Endemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia duttoni, Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia parkeri, etc, and is transmitted by ticks.

questions.text: During a louse outbreak among jail inmates, a few of them developed fevers that subsided after 3-5 days. The fever relapsed after a week and subsided again. Many patients had tender splenomegaly on examination. Which culture medium is used to isolate the organism implicated here?

choices.text: Mannitol, egg-yolk, phenol red, polymyxin agar

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of louse-born relapsing fever (LBRF) caused by Borrelia recurrentis. Barbour-Stoenner-Kelly broth medium is used to isolate all Borrelia species except for B.miyaotoi.

Tender splenomegaly and relapsing fever in the background of a louse outbreak point towards the diagnosis of LBRF. 

It was very common during wars and in the jails of former days but with improvements in hygiene and the discovery of insecticides, it has now become rare.

questions.text: Which one of the following micro-organisms uses antigenic variation as a major means of evading the host immune system?
questions.solution:
Borrelia recurrentis uses antigenic variation as a major means of evading the host immune system. It causes relapsing fever. 

Borrelia readily undergoes antigenic variations in vivo and this is believed to be the reason for the occurrence of relapses in the disease. Antigenic variations occur because of DNA rearrangements in linear plasmids present in borrelia.

questions.text: A 23 year old  presented with fever, myalgia, and skin lesion as shown in the image. What is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows erythema migrans, seen in Lyme disease. It is caused by Borrelia Burgdoferi. 

The lesion has a target center with partial central clearing and a  bright red outer border. It usually begins as a red macule or papule at the site of the tick bite.

The tick implicated is the black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis, shown in the image below.

The most severe manifestation of Lyme disease is Lyme neuroborreliosis (LNB), reported in 10–15% of individuals with localized erythema migrans. The activation of the inflammatory response in LNB contributes to the pathogenesis of a broad spectrum of neurologic disorders.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: Following a flood, there is an outbreak of fever. Water samples from various sources are being studied for pathogens. The bacteria shown in the given image was isolated as a potential cause of disease. Which of the following animals is the most important reservoir of these organisms?
questions.solution:
The electron micrograph shows the spirochete, Leptospira interrogans, which causes the water-borne disease, leptospirosis. Rats are the most important reservoir. 

Transmission of leptospires may follow direct contact with urine, blood, or tissue from an infected animal or exposure to environmental contamination.

questions.text: A farmer who works in paddy fields presented with fever, intense myalgia, and hematochezia. Lab investigations showed sharply elevated creatinine levels and high liver enzymes. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Weil's disease which is caused by leptospira.

Long hours of working in a field with water (paddy field), is a high-risk factor for the development of leptospirosis. 

Weil’s syndrome is the severe form of leptospirosis that encompasses the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.text: At a relief camp in Karnataka, a few people developed fever, myalgia, and conjunctival suffusion. Rapid diagnostic IgM ELISA tests performed in the field showed leptospirosis. Which of the following culture media can be used to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used for leptospira.

Other culture media that can be used are Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media. 

The image below shows EMJH medium, with Dinger's ring/zone. The growth of the leptospires is at a maximum density at this zone. It is identified as an area of increased turbidity, beneath the surface of the semi-solid medium. It is the zone of optimum oxygen tension for the growth of the bacteria.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Serotype-specific tests:  

  • Microscopic agglutination test 
  • Macroscopic agglutination test  

Option A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid fever

Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  

Option D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.

Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Weil’s syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone. 

The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis.

 Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by microscopic agglutination test. 

Transmission occurs through cuts or breaks in the skin and mucous membranes (conjunctival and oral mucosa). Several outbreaks have been reported that resulted from exposure to floodwaters contaminated by urine from infected animals. The organism enters the bloodstream and lodges in the parenchymatous organs (liver and kidneys) leading to hemorrhage and necrosis of the tissue causing dysfunction of the organs.

The lifecycle of Leptospira is shown below.

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are: 

  • Acute leptospiremic phase- the organism can be cultured from blood.
  • Resolving immune phase- the organism can be cultured from urine.

The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.

Other options:

Option A - Chikungunya is a viral disease that presents with saddle-back fever, conjunctival suffusion, and photophobia. Migratory arthralgia, especially involving small joints may also be seen. A maculopapular or petechial rash is frequently seen on the trunk.

Option C - Dengue hemorrhagic fever is a form of severe dengue with bleeding manifestations. Evidence of plasma leakage and thrombocytopenia is also generally seen. 

Option D - Encephalitis due to Hepatitis A is seen in fulminant hepatitis, a rare complication. Patients present with confusion, disorientation, ascites, and edema.
